Central Berlin is expecting gridlock next Tuesday when the Franco-German political elite assembles to mark the 50th anniversary of the Elysée treaty, the pact that sealed the postwar reconciliation of the two countries and propelled the great project of European unification.
Six months of intensive planning will culminate on January 22 in a symbolic meeting of more than 1,000 French and German MPs in the Reichstag, followed by a concert for 2,000 guests in Berlin’s Philharmonie. Town halls and schools across both countries will celebrate 50 years of friendship between the old adversaries.
The only trouble is that nobody told David Cameron. The British prime minister has been promising a “big speech” on his quest to loosen the UK’s European relationship since last autumn and last Friday he had finally settled on a preferred date: January 22. His officials thought Germany might be a suitable venue.
As his plan leaked out, anguished calls arrived at Downing Street from the UK embassy in Berlin and the office of Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, expressing incredulity that Mr Cameron might make his speech on this day of all days.
But this was more than a diplomatic blunder: it symbolised Britain’s awkward relationship with Europe, where misunderstandings on both sides are common. British officials later admitted they had no idea of the significance of the Elysée treaty event.
Mr Cameron finally decided to end what he has called the “tantric” wait for his speech on Europe by rushing it forward to this Friday, to be delivered at a venue in the Netherlands – a country regarded by Britain as a free-trading ally.
Mr Cameron wants to clarify Britain’s future relationship with the EU and pacify his eurosceptic Conservative party. That may be wishful thinking: previous Tory prime ministers have tried and failed. Will the Amsterdam speech raise as many questions as it answers? The prime minister is expected in his speech to pledge to negotiate a better EU deal for Britain if he wins the next election in 2015 and offer the British people their first vote on Europe since 1975. “A fresh settlement and then fresh consent for that settlement,” he said this week.
In making his speech in continental Europe, Mr Cameron is following past Tory leaders who hoped to show that their views could command a respectful audience beyond the white cliffs of Dover and to provide a geographical illustration of their commitment to Europe (albeit with trademark British reservations).
Winston Churchill’s Zurich speech in 1946 urged France and Germany to forge a United States of Europe – although Britain would naturally not be part of it. Margaret Thatcher proclaimed in her 1988 Bruges speech her opposition to a European “superstate”, although her hardline admirers often overlook another passage: “Britain does not dream of some cosy, isolated existence on the fringes of the European Community. Our destiny is in Europe, as part of the community.”
John Major chose Leiden University in the Netherlands to make the case for a multi-speed Europe, but with the caveat: “The British people know that their future rests with being part of the European Union.” That reassurance is being offered by Mr Cameron this week in a round of telephone diplomacy to Europe’s chancelleries.
For all his charm, some leaders do not take Mr Cameron entirely at his word. Werner Faymann, the Austrian chancellor, told Der Standard this month: “Why I have a hard time with David Cameron ... and when it comes to trust, it is because I get the feeling with him that he speaks differently in his own country than he does in the European Council.”
That is perhaps unsurprising given that many European leaders view Mr Cameron’s policy through the filter of the largely eurosceptic British press. “I have to keep telling my colleagues in Brussels not to read the bloody Daily Express,” said one British cabinet minister of the hostile tabloid.
Denis MacShane, a former Labour Europe minister, says there may be a simple explanation of why Downing Street missed the celebrations in Berlin and why other EU leaders are suspicious of Mr Cameron: “They read our papers and we don’t read theirs.”
But there is more to it than that. While Mr Cameron has been reassuring European leaders that he wants Britain to remain a strong player in the EU, he told fellow Tory MPs behind closed doors last month that they would enjoy the tough tone of his speech when it came. “He told us we’d really love it – that it would be really eurosceptic,” says one MP.
Mr Cameron’s precarious attempt to balance his dual role as European statesman and party manager is a familiar one to Tory prime ministers and one which ultimately defeated both Lady Thatcher and Mr Major.
Today the overwhelming view among Tory MPs is that Britain must seize upon the crisis in the eurozone to secure a new British settlement in Europe. While perhaps 30 to 40 of the Tories’ 303 MPs will not be happy until Britain is out of the EU altogether, the majority say they want to stay in, but on new terms. Andrea Leadsom, an MP from the mainstream eurosceptic Fresh Start group, characterises the approach as “more trade, less of the other stuff”.
Even Nick Clegg, Mr Cameron’s pro-European deputy, recognises that Britain’s membership of the euro is “not likely to happen in my political lifetime” and that the UK must defend the single market’s integrity against eurozone members acting as a caucus and decreeing terms to London.
George Osborne, the chancellor, made a promising start before Christmas, winning the support of Germany among others for new voting rules to protect the interests of the euro “outs” in the field of banking supervision, although the Fresh Start Tories want to go further with an “emergency brake” – a veto – to safeguard the City.
But Mr Clegg fears that a desirable drive to clarify the relationship between the eurozone and the long-term “outs” (of which Britain is by far the biggest) is undermined by Mr Cameron’s “fantasy” second objective: seizing back existing powers from Brussels. The Fresh Start Tories have presented Mr Cameron with a shopping list that includes employment and social law, fisheries, regional policy, justice and policing.
Mr Cameron has hinted he might block any EU treaty changes to reinforce the eurozone unless he won back some powers, arguing Britain was “not just entitled but actually enabled – because they need the changes – to ask for changes ourselves”. But that strategy may run into an immediate roadblock if eurozone members decide – as seems increasingly possible – that they can strengthen the currency without a formal treaty revision.
. . .

Mr Cameron’s comments sparked dismay in Berlin, with Gunther Krichbaum, an ally of Ms Merkel from the Christian Democratic Union, accusing him of “blackmailing” other states. Ms Merkel also fears that Mr Cameron’s plan to unpick existing policies could create a free-for-all, with France and other protectionist-minded countries trying to undo the rules governing the single market – the part of the EU that Mr Cameron likes most. But Tory MPs believe that, after considerable grumbling, Ms Merkel will ultimately help Mr Cameron, fearing that a “Brexit” would tilt the EU in favour of a less economically liberal southern European bloc. Senior officials in Berlin, however, warn that there is a limit to German tolerance of a special deal for the UK. “Our red line is clear: no cherry picking,” says one minister.
The possibility of Mr Cameron failing to get a much better deal raises a question that he has been unable to answer: how can he commit to fighting for a Yes vote (to stay in the union) in a referendum if he does not know how negotiations will turn out?
If he does campaign for a Yes vote and the country votes No, would that automatically lead to a British exit? And would a No vote bring down the government? If so, would it not give voters a motive to use the referendum (possibly in 2017 or 2018) to protest against an unpopular midterm administration in a climate of austerity?
A YouGov poll found this month that 42 per cent of Britons wanted to leave the EU and 36 per cent wanted to stay, although the same pollster found a recent swell in the majority in favour of membership when asked how they would vote if Mr Cameron secured a better deal for UK interests.
While that may support Mr Cameron’s belief he can win a referendum, unpopular leaders in pro-European countries including France, Ireland and the Netherlands know to their cost that voters in EU referendums are not exclusively answering the question on the ballot paper. “Europe is not the primary interest of the British public,” says Ken Clarke, the veteran pro-European minister.
Mr Cameron has so far failed to answer perhaps the biggest question posed by business. Asked whether he could guarantee Britain would still be a EU member in five years, the prime minister declined to answer.
“He’s spent six years preparing a speech to create five years of uncertainty for Britain,” says Ed Miliband, leader of the Labour opposition.
. . .

During the long wait for his speech, Mr Cameron’s position has increasingly been framed by others. The US has warned that Britain risked “turning inward” if it held a referendum, stressing that Washington wanted the UK to stay inside the European club, to shape debate.
Mr Clegg, leader of the Liberal Democrats, the Tories’ junior coalition partner, warned of the “chilling” effect the uncertainty might have on inward investment, while Lord Heseltine, Mr Cameron’s growth adviser, said multinationals might shun Britain. European diplomats ask why they should make concessions if they keep reading in the UK press that London is going to leave anyway.
Mr Cameron’s Amsterdam address might have tested Cicero. The prime minister has to convince his sceptical party that he is hanging tough with Europe, while persuading EU leaders he remains a committed player. He has to appeal to the Tory heart which wants to disengage from Brussels and to the party’s head, which recognises the need to stay. He has to signal that he sees Britain’s future in the EU, without throwing away his negotiating hand: a veiled threat to withdraw if he does not get his way.
Even if it all goes to plan, Mr Cameron can still expect a referendum campaign in the next parliament with a highly uncertain outcome which could yet split his party: at least some MPs and ministers are likely to fight for an exit. One Tory MP quipped that it was just as well Mr Cameron “won’t win the next election”. But what if he does? Little wonder Mr Cameron has procrastinated for months before his arrival in Amsterdam.
Additional reporting by Quentin Peel

Over the past seven months, David Cameron has curried favour with dozens of big beasts of the European political scene, from heads of government to backroom fixers and the panjandrums of the European parliament. But five key relationships have shaped the prime minister’s drive to reset the UK's relations with the EU. 
François Hollande

Often frosty, sometimes unpredictable, Mr Cameron’s relationship with François Hollande is one of the most delicate factors in his search for a UK deal. Their first meeting started with a promising exchange. Aides recall Mr Cameron’s breaking into a smile when Mr Hollande said he wanted eurozone integration — while accommodating the concerns of euro-outs such as Britain. 
Putting that into practice has been tricky — as Mr Hollande and Mr Cameron’s mulish encounters into the early hours of Friday attests. They disagree over Britain demand for treaty change, and Mr Cameron’s protests over the EU meddling with the City of London. 
Low points include an excruciating staged visit to an Oxfordshire pub where Mr Hollande spurned the house ale for a glass of red wine. But the terror attacks in France helped to transform their interactions as Britain and France’s intelligence and military ties came to the fore. The rapprochement was encapsulated by Mr Cameron’s rush to Paris following the November attacks to stand side by side with Mr Hollande at the Bataclan concert hall. 
Donald Tusk

Donald Tusk, as European Council president, has played sympathetic broker for Mr Cameron’s “new settlement” and brought political mettle to chairing  the talks. But rewind a few years, and the omens were not good. As Poland’s premier, Mr Tusk backed a big EU budget and uninhibited free movement at a time when Mr Cameron wanted to slash EU spending and discourage more Polish workers from coming to Britain. 
When Mr Cameron called for an end to British child benefit payments being exported to Warsaw, Mr Tusk angrily accused him of attempting to “stigmatise” Poles. The differences convinced Mr Cameron to initially opposed Mr Tusk’s nomination to be Council president, even though they got on personally and shared a liberal economic outlook and wariness of Russia. 
The reconciliation came in an August call from Mr Cameron’s holiday home in Cornwall. With a little nudge from Berlin — and the realisation that Mr Tusk was a dead cert for the Council job — Mr Cameron switched horses to back Mr Tusk. Their fates are now tied. “Everyone knows the personal success of Cameron is the only way to save Britain in Europe,” said a senior Polish official close to Mr Tusk. “And if Brexit happens, Tusk is dead.” 
Jean-Claude Juncker

The start could hardly had been worse. Mr Cameron tried and humiliatingly failed to kill Jean-Claude Juncker’s bid for the European Commission presidency. The British prime minister saw Mr Juncker as a political dinosaur who epitomised of all that was wrong with the European project. 
But the veteran Luxembourgish prime minister showed his knack for fixing problems — even of a British size — over the past two years. The two leaders made up soon after his appointment, partly after Mr Cameron expressed “regret” for British tabloids bringing Mr Juncker’s father to tears with hurtful stories over his “Nazi” past (the former steelworker was forcibly conscripted and wounded on the eastern front). 
And while Mr Juncker has doggedly warned Mr Cameron not to push too far with his demand for migrant benefit curbs, his Commission staff found a neat compromise through an “emergency brake”. 
Stung by past run-ins with Tony Blair over the EU budget, Mr Juncker has long advised a cool head with London. “Normally with Britain you negotiate always three times,” he told friends. “There is always three dramas, and you end up with three protocols and 15-side declarations . . . It’s always like that. You have to be patient.” 
Jaroslaw Kaczy?ski

David Cameron was on his third visit to Poland in nine months when he was finally granted the audience he sought to get the Poles to agree to his EU reform proposals: a one-on-one meeting with Jaroslaw Kaczy?ski. Mr Kaczy?ski, leader of Poland's ruling Law and Justice party, pulls the strings of Warsaw’s new government. 
He chose not to run for high office, delegating those roles to party officials instead, and now sits atop the country's political power structures. If you want to get something done in the EU's sixth-largest economy, you need his blessing.  Mr Cameron and Mr Kaczynski have history — their two parties formed the European Conservative and Reformist group in the European Parliament, now its third-largest bloc — and are both mild eurosceptics who think national capitals need to regain some power from Brussels. 
Belligerent and combative in public, Mr Kaczy?ski is quiet and thoughtful in private, and met Mr Cameron in February in a function room at The Bristol, Warsaw's most exclusive hotel. In a shower of flashbulbs, the two men sank into soft cream chairs for a 40-minute discussion, where Mr Cameron pressed Mr Kaczy?ski to agree to his terms as a means to keep the UK in the EU. Mr Kaczy?ski was convinced. “We have gained really very, very much,” a smiling Mr Kaczy?ski said after the meeting. In the final hours of the this week’s summit, though, Poland dug in.
Angela Merkel

Like old friends, Angela Merkel and David Cameron looked noticeably at ease with each other when they met this month at a glittering Hamburg dinner held to celebrate Anglo-German co-operation. Mr Cameron has in the past been a bit over-reliant on Ms Merkel, trusting to her skills to fix things for Britain in the EU. Europe’s paramount leader has usually shown willing but not always delivered, as she tried to balance promises to Mr Cameron with other pressures. 
She failed to stop the 2011 fiscal pact despite saying she would try to accommodate Mr Cameron’s objections, and in 2014 she was obliged to abandon her support for Mr Cameron’s effort to block Jean-Claude Juncker’s accession as European Commission president. This time, Mr Cameron heeded her advice not to depend on her backing alone in his push for EU reform — and he sought allies in other capitals. 
With his privileged Old Etonian background, the smooth-talking 49-year-old British prime minister is a quite different political animal from the reserved 61-year-old ex-scientist from the former Communist East Germany. But they have made friends with Ms Merkel reportedly treating her younger colleague as a “naughty nephew”, tolerating both his jokes and his sometimes less than EU-friendly utterings. Oddly, they have a common interest in the British television crime drama, Midsomer Murders, which they have watched together at Chequers, the British prime minister’s country home.

A British exit from the EU is “unimaginable”, according to Germany’s powerful finance minister, and Berlin will do everything in its power to keep the UK part of the union following the clash over Jean-Claude Juncker’s appointment as European Commission president.
Wolfgang Schäuble told the Financial Times an EU without its island neighbour would be “absolutely not acceptable”, ahead of Europe’s largest economy taking over the presidency of the Group of Seven industrialised nations on Tuesday.
Mr Schäuble’s comments came amid bridge-building between David Cameron and Mr Juncker in a phone call in which the UK prime minister congratulated the commission’s president-elect and the latter said he was committed to finding solutions to British political concerns.
On Friday, after being defeated 26-2 by fellow EU leaders over Mr Juncker’s appointment, Mr Cameron said it was “a bad day Europe”. But on Monday he insisted he would work with the new commission president, noting that Mr Juncker had committed in his manifesto to working for a fair deal with Britain.
Writing in the Daily Telegraph, Mr Cameron said: “If by a fair deal, we can agree that we are not heading, at different speeds, to the same place – as some have assumed up to now – then there is business we can do.”
Lord Mandelson, Britain’s former EU commissioner, said that during a private meeting with Mr Junker in Germany last week, Mr Junker had told him he was willing to do business with Mr Cameron, as he believed that a British exit “would not just be a catastrophe for Britain, but a disaster for Europe as a whole”.
Speaking to BBC’s Radio 4’s Today programme on Monday morning, Lord Mandelson added: “He explicitly said he does not advocate a United States of Europe . . . he’s not a green-eyed federalist monster.”
Meanwhile, the CBI, the British business lobby group, warned on Sunday that UK economic growth depended on the country remaining a full member of the EU. Opposition leader Ed Miliband also lashed out at Mr Cameron, saying the prime minister was a “real and present danger” to the British economy over his failure in Brussels last Friday to stop Mr Juncker’s nomination.
Mr Schäuble, one of German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s closest confidants and a veteran of many EU disputes, argued that Britain’s EU membership was particularly important for Germany as London and Berlin share a market-oriented reform approach. “Clearly, we have in many economic questions and regulatory questions a broad consensus,” he said.
“Historically, politically, democratically, culturally, Great Britain is entirely indispensable for Europe,” he added, pointing out that “by a great distance” London was one of the world’s most important financial centres.
Asked whether the EU had been damaged by the Juncker row, Mr Schäuble said: “Democracy always involves arguments, and European integration is a development, which is seen a bit differently in the [different] member states . . . But I am quite confident [about the EU’s future].”
An unabashed EU integrationist, he praised the European Parliament’s success in pushing Ms Merkel and most other EU government heads into backing Mr Juncker. While Mr Cameron has condemned the move as “a power grab”, Mr Schäuble said: “You Britons have, if I have this right, strongly promoted parliamentarianism in European history. And that must also take place in Europe.”
The German finance minister brushed aside recent calls for more flexibility in the eurozone’s stability pact to allow debt-ridden countries more leeway to promote growth.
These have come from the centre-left, including Italian prime minister Matteo Renzi and Sigmar Gabriel, the German social democrat leader and Ms Merkel’s coalition partner.
Mr Schäuble said: “In Europe, I haven’t heard this demand either from the Italian prime minister or from anyone else . . .[In Germany] we have clear arrangements within the coalition. Besides, I am the finance minister in this federal government and we’re doing this on the basis of this collective arrangement. Mr Gabriel has explicitly stated that he does not demand any adjustment in the European excessive deficit procedure – quite the opposite.”
And in words that will win few friends in debt-laden southern Europe, Mr Schäuble added: “As I always say – we mustn’t talk about adjustments. We have to do what it states in the rules. We must do what is agreed. We have to implement. The problem in Europe is not the rules but the implementation – sometimes.”
Mr Schäuble repeated Germany’s commitment to tightening the eurozone through institutional reforms “the sooner the better”. But he acknowledged radical changes requiring treaty revision would be difficult for many states – a view that highlights Mr Cameron’s difficulties in pursuing the EU-diluting treaty revision that he seeks.
As for Germany’s G7 presidency plans, the finance minister said: “The paramount theme is how we can achieve sustainable growth.”
Germany will also pursue existing G7 programmes for financial reform, including improving supervision and limiting taxpayers’ exposure to future bank failures, as well as tightening tax rules globally.
As a high-tax country, Germany wants to limit tax competition from low-tax states such as Ireland. Mr Schäuble said he aimed to reduce “tax flexibility to the level that is compatible with the rules of fairness”.
Additional reporting by Helen Warrell and Claer Barrett in London

Be honest: where is the EU going? / From Mr Kenneth Armitage

David Cameron has urged Jean-Claude Juncker to give Britain a top economic post in his new European Commisison, but has been warned that the Luxembourger has “not forgotten” the personal attacks made on him by London.
Mr Cameron was given a hero’s welcome by Conservative MPs in the House of Commons yesterday, as he defended his decision to oppose Mr Juncker’s appointment “right to the end”.
More cheers came when Mr Cameron said he would do what was in “the national interest” if he failed in his bid to reform Britain’s EU membership, a hint to Tory MPs that he might yet campaign for the UK to leave the EU.
But away from Westminster, Mr Cameron engaged in a delicate attempt to rebuild relations in Brussels. The British prime minister telephoned Mr Juncker on Sunday to congratulate him on a “successful campaign”.
Those close to Mr Juncker say he will not forget the aggressive nature of the attacks – conveyed through a hostile British press – which they believe were orchestrated by the PM. 
“Mr Juncker has been around for a long time, he has dealt with many political conflicts but he made it clear to Cameron that he did not appreciate the personal attacks against him,” said an EU diplomat close to Mr Juncker.
“They portrayed him as a monster and that’s not acceptable.” The diplomat added: “It’s now all forgiven but not forgotten.”
The resentment caused by Mr Cameron’s failed campaign to stop Mr Juncker – which ended in a 26-2 defeat at a Brussels summit last Friday – could have lasting consequences.
Mr Cameron wants a Briton to take a senior economics role in the new Brussels team; the single market, competition and energy are the main roles sought. The allocation of top jobs is expected to be discussed at an EU summit on July 16.
The prime minister also needs Mr Juncker to help deliver a renegotiation of Britain’s EU membership. And while Mr Juncker says he is “fully committed to finding solutions for the political concerns of the UK”, he is under pressure not to reward Mr Cameron for his intransigence.
The diplomat close to Mr Juncker said that “the UK would be treated fairly” but warned that large countries that had openly supported the former Grand Duchy premier in the nomination process expected something in return. 
“Some of these countries will say: ‘We have supported you, you can’t go around giving the UK a special treatment now [to patch this up]’,” the diplomat said. France, Germany and Spain were among the supporters of Mr Juncker.
The EU diplomat said weekend talks between the two leaders were the start of what could be a very long period before relations return to normal.
Mr Cameron was mocked in the Commons by Ed Miliband, Labour leader, for giving “a masterclass on how to alienate allies” through a combination of “threats, insults and disengagement”, as he tried and failed to build an anti-Juncker coalition.
But Conservatives cheered the prime minister for defending “a point of principle” that elected EU leaders should choose the commission president; Mr Juncker’s appointment was demanded by the European parliament.
When Mr Miliband questioned why so many leaders – including Angela Merkel, German chancellor – initially appeared to oppose Mr Juncker and then changed their minds, some Tory MPs jeered: “Liars.”
Mr Cameron’s predominantly eurosceptic party has rallied behind him, with MPs lining up to praise his tough negotiating tactics in spite of the fact he ended up virtually isolated in Brussels with only Hungary’s Viktor Orbán in his camp.
The Tory right believes Mr Cameron can win the 2015 general election and are falling in behind him, knowing that they will only secure their cherished referendum on British membership of the EU in 2017 if the Conservatives triumph.
Senior Tories admit the party will split during a referendum campaign with between 30 and 40 MPs likely to vote for a British exit under any circumstances; many others will vote No if Mr Cameron fails to deliver a successful EU renegotiation.
Some moderate Tory MPs believe he has already ceded too much ground to the right.
“There are growing divisions within the party with increasingly irreconcilable eurosceptics believing that they have had it their own way and that they have the prime minister on the run,” said one pro-European Tory MP.
John Baron, a leading eurosceptic who is leaning towards leaving the European Union without significant reforms, told the FT the prime minister has “played the man, now he must play the ball” by explaining exactly how he intends to reform the EU.
Additional reporting by Elizabeth Rigby

Cameron is no returning hero / From Mr Kurt Vermeulen

In promising a referendum David Cameron signposted the route for Britain’s departure from the EU. Unsurprisingly, a deeply eurosceptic Conservative party is now unceremoniously bundling the prime minister along this path. Exit has long been a plausible outcome of the endless Tory paroxysms. It has begun to look a probability. This is a sobering thought, and not only for foreign investors thinking about where to put their money.
When Harold Wilson gave Britons a plebiscite on EU membership in 1975 the then British leader was not thinking about the national interest. He wanted to bridge divisions in his own, half-sceptic party. A sham renegotiation to secure better membership terms was followed by a government call for a Yes vote. Wilson won the day, and, for a time, quelled the anti-Europe rebellion.
Faced with his own eurosceptic insurgency, Mr Cameron imagined he could pull off a similar coup. The realities of coalition politics with the Liberal Democrats precluded an immediate referendum, so he promised a vote if the Tories won the 2015 election. The ploy, quite predictably, has failed. Sceptics have learnt a lot since 1975. They have been emboldened rather than placated by the referendum pledge. 
As was evident during his talks this week with Barack Obama at the White House, on the question of Europe the prime minister is in office but not in power. A prominent, Conservative-minded commentator describes him as the “bullied child in the playground”. However many sweets he hands his tormentors, they want more. Mr Cameron interrupted his US trip to rush out a draft of his proposed referendum bill. The sceptics demanded more.
The present condition of the Tories invites a second parallel, this time with the left of the Labour party during the early 1980s. Defeat at the hands of Margaret Thatcher in 1979 shattered Wilson’s truce. Labour fought the 1983 election on promises to quit the EU, scrap Britain’s nuclear weapons and nationalise the banks and much of industry. When Thatcher won a bigger majority the left, bizarrely, claimed that this was because Labour’s prospectus had been insufficiently radical. 
The same surreal absolutism now energises the eurosceptic right. It is true that British voters have never been enthusiasts for Europe. They have scarcely been won over by the crisis in the eurozone. The immigration associated with the EU’s eastern enlargement has been exploited by the populist UK Independence party. The narrative peddled by Ukip – Britain’s troubles are all the fault of outsiders – has resonance in tough economic times. For their part, Tory sceptics hum a curiously defeatist tune: Britain is doomed forever to be the victim, rather than a leader, in Europe. 
They are reading, though, only one side of public opinion. While most voters do not much like Brussels, they are not obsessed by it. When they are asked to rank the EU in the list of things most salient to their daily lives, it rarely makes the top 10. Most people have more pressing concerns such as living standards and jobs, hospitals and schools. 
Never mind. The next demand of the Tory sceptics will be that Mr Cameron set out his demands for the promised renegotiation with Britain’s partners. He must spell out precisely which powers will be repatriated to the Westminster parliament, which EU policies Britain will opt out of, and the guarantees that will be secured against further integration.
So far Mr Cameron has sensibly confined himself to generalities. Who can disagree with a call for Europe to be more competitive and open to the world and to interfere less in the nooks and crannies of national life? It is when the talk turns to special privileges and exemptions for Britain that things get tricky.
The other day I heard a senior figure in Angela Merkel’s government express palpable horror at the prospect of British departure. It would be a serious blow to Europe as well as to Britain. Ms Merkel, he continued, would do all she could to assuage concerns that eurozone integration could leave Britain marginalised in EU decision-making. Berlin could sign up also to an outward-looking, less intrusive EU.
The German and other EU governments, however, have their own red lines. It is one thing to offer Britain assurances about the future, quite another to allow any member to opt out of parts of the union’s acquis – the accumulated body of European law and agreements – that it finds inconvenient. To accept that approach would be to begin to unravel the entire enterprise.
This points up the central contradiction that has doomed Mr Cameron’s tactics from the outset. The Tory sceptics, now in a majority in the party, divide between those who want Britain simply to leave the EU and those who say they would consider staying in on radically different terms. These terms, however, challenge such basic tenets of the union as free movement of people, the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice and the single market. They strike at the heart of the notion that the EU is a supranational institution. Britain’s partners cannot but say No. 
There is a more than remote possibility, of course, that Mr Cameron will be unable to deliver on his pledge. Winning the next election will be more than a challenge. But decidedly ragged as the government now looks, Ed Miliband’s Labour is scarcely a credible government-in-waiting. The opposition lead in the polls is soft and Mr Miliband could yet be panicked into matching the Tory referendum pledge. A Labour government would quite likely lose such a plebiscite. So there’s the final rub. Mr Cameron could lose the election and bequeath, as a deferred legacy, Britain’s flight from Europe.

As David Cameron emerged just after midnight, the bags under his eyes bore witness to what had been an awkward round of summit diplomacy. 
The UK prime minister’s dinnertime exposition on what Jean-Claude Juncker, European Commission president, called “the British problem” spanned the starter of chicken terrine and threatened to interrupt the filet de biche. It was “not quite Castro length, but approaching”, said one person in attendance.
This was what Donald Tusk, European Council president, described as a “make or break” moment for Mr Cameron’s push for a new settlement for Britain, the first occasion for his blueprint for reform to be frankly debated by EU leaders as a group. 
What played out over the four-hour session, including 30-plus interventions, was a mix of statecraft, emotion, cries of “blackmail” and subtle legal gymnastics that diplomats hope will frame a deal in February fit for Mr Cameron to keep Britain in the EU. 
There is plenty of hard bargaining to come. Mr Juncker said it was an “illusion” to imagine any of Mr Cameron’s demands were “easy”. But those closely involved in the negotiations see the Thursday night session as breaking a worrying political deadlock on Mr Cameron’s most contentious demands on benefits for migrants, thereby clearing space for a compromise on all areas of the package. 
Most significantly, Mr Tusk said even Mr Cameron had agreed that overt discrimination was wrong — a concession that restarts the search for alternatives to his widely opposed proposal for a four-year ban on migrant workers claiming British tax credits. 
Yet for all the cautious optimism it was, at times, a raw and forthright exchange. There were impassioned interventions from opponents of Britain’s migration demands, including Portuguese Prime Minister António Costa. Dalia Grybauskait?, the Lithuanian president renowned for frank speaking and a black-belt in karate, did little to hide her irritation with what she called Mr Cameron’s “blackmail” tactics.
More leaders than expected raised concerns about giving national parliaments a bigger say over EU legislation. And eurozone leaders in particular made clear that Mr Cameron’s search for “safeguards” for non-euro members would never be allowed to leave the euro countries at a disadvantage or hamper the decision-making of the currency bloc. “The discussion was — how to say it in diplomatic language — frank . . . but at the same time open,” said François Hollande, French president. 
As is often the case in Brussels, it was Angela Merkel of Germany who set the tone and direction of the early debate, speaking soon after Mr Cameron and making clear the common interest in avoiding Brexit without having to rewrite the core principles of the union. 
Ireland’s Prime Minister Enda Kenny also weighed in on Mr Cameron’s side, recalling how Britain had bailed out his country during the eurozone crisis and now deserved the help of all those around the table. 
While some leaders — including Mr Hollande — made clear that they were against any treaty change, a compromise was laid out by Ms Merkel and several others: a postdated promise of treaty change, similar to the accord offered to Denmark in 1992. 
“I think what’s come out clearly is that if we need treaty changes — and I think this might be so — then we all agree that this doesn’t happen now. In line with the British proposal, this could happen later,” the German chancellor said.
The question was how to make this tally with Mr Cameron’s four-year demand, which Mr Hollande said “seemed to many [in tonight’s talks] to be very long and difficult to reconcile with the treaties”.

David Cameron is pursuing his fight to block Jean-Claude Juncker’s appointment as European Commission president to the bitter end, even if he appears to be heading for a crushing defeat.
Downing St admits that Mr Cameron may be almost completely isolated if Mr Juncker’s appointment is put to a vote at a Brussels summit on Friday – only Hungary is likely to support him. But he sees the fight as a point of principle; he claims that many other leaders share his concerns but are afraid to speak out.
The British prime minister wants elected EU leaders to call the shots on who runs the commission. Mr Juncker is the candidate of the European parliament. Moreover Mr Cameron believes for the former Luxembourg premier, a veteran Brussels insider, is the wrong person to lead Europe on a new path of reform.
His apparently futile battle has cross-party support in the UK and is popular with British voters: a Populus/FT poll this week found that voters approve of his stand. They say that by a margin of 2:1 he will be seen as “strong” even if he loses.
What will Mr Cameron do if he loses and Mr Juncker is appointed? 
This is the great unknown: Mr Cameron has already issued dark hints to fellow heads of government that they will push Britain closer to the exit if they appoint Mr Juncker.
Downing St has done its best to fan the uncertainty about what Mr Cameron might say or do next, a tactic partly designed to persuade other EU leaders – including Angela Merkel, German chancellor – to back down at the last minute.
Mr Cameron has suggested that he might bring forward his proposed 2017 in-out referendum while Number 10 has not denied speculation that the prime minister might announce that he will campaign for Britain to leave.
That seems highly unlikely: British business and the City want Britain to remain in the EU. But Mr Cameron is likely to use his defeat to reinforce the need for other big concessions to help him persuade Britain to stay in the EU.
What sort of concessions?
Mr Cameron has made a range of demands, including restrictions on migrant workers’ rights to benefits, the transfer of more decision-making to national parliaments, and the exclusion of Britain from the EU’s “ever closer union” mission.
But the prime minister will also want Britain to secure other senior jobs in Brussels as a counterweight to Mr Juncker. Britain is looking to secure a top economic job in the new commission, with energy seen as one option. 
Meanwhile there has been speculation that a British eurocrat – possibly Jonathan Faull, currently director-general of the EU’s powerful internal market directorate – could become the commission’s secretary-general. That post would put a Brit into the commission’s top civil service role working closely with Mr Juncker.
Could Mr Cameron be bought off with any of these things at this late stage?
No. Mr Cameron has told Herman Van Rompuy, the EU Council president, that he is not interested in any “backroom deals” and that if his fellow summiteers decide to press ahead with Mr Juncker’s appointment he will force a vote – ending a long tradition that the Council acts by consensus.

A question being asked by many in Brussels, where Mr Cameron’s battle to stop the “Junckernaut” is seen as British obstructionism. Some argue that Mr Cameron should be punished rather than rewarded for his stance and that he has blown any chance of getting Brits into top jobs.
But Mr Cameron may not have exhausted all goodwill. Angela Merkel, German chancellor, had offered to help the British prime minister block Mr Juncker but was prevented from doing so by domestic politics: she may feel she owes him a favour.
Germany wants to keep Britain in the EU, fearing that a Brexit would leave Berlin struggling to contain a southern European bloc, including France, Spain and Italy, who do not necessarily share Ms Merkel’s enthusiasm for budget rigour and free trade.

David Cameron had not expected to win outright. But Britain’s electorate had just presented the prime minister with a spectacular election victory and the rest of Europe with a big problem. “We have got a mandate,” Mr Cameron told journalists in the House of Commons as he prepared to address 300 jubilant Conservative MPs last week. “It’s going to be tough but we have a mandate.”
Mr Cameron’s victory means that he now has to make good on his promise to put the country’s membership of the EU to a referendum, a high-risk strategy intended to pacify his eurosceptic party and settle a question that has bedevilled British politics since the country last voted on the issue 40 years ago.
Angela Merkel, Germany’s chancellor, declared Mr Cameron’s victory as “simply great”; François Hollande, French president, invited the British leader to Paris. But behind the diplomatic niceties was a simple calculation: the time has now come for Europe to address the “British question”.
While Europe has been obsessed in recent years by a potential Greek exit from the eurozone, the possibility of a British exit from the EU has suddenly assumed even greater significance for the 28-member club. “For Britain it would be a disaster; for Germany it would be a catastrophe,” admits one senior German minister.
For Britain, a trading nation, unlimited access to a single market of 500m consumers could be called into doubt. Deutsche Bank this week announced it could move operations out of Britain if the country voted to leave in a referendum, which Mr Cameron has promised by the end of 2017. Brexit could even accelerate the break-up of the United Kingdom: polls show Scots remain firmly in favour of EU membership.
The departure of Britain would be an unprecedented blow to the European project. The UK might be a troublesome member that is badly trying the patience of its allies, but it adds global reach, military force, budgetary discipline and liberal instincts to a Europe suffering a crisis of confidence. 

Both sides have much to lose. The question being asked in European capitals is what is Mr Cameron’s price — he insists there has to be fundamental reform of the EU for Britain to remain a member — and can we afford to pay it?
Mr Cameron is bullish. He wants to use his newfound electoral authority to press ahead with his renegotiation starting tomorrow in informal talks with EU leaders on the margins of a summit in the Latvian capital Riga.
Next week he will introduce a parliamentary bill to pave the way for his in-out referendum; Philip Hammond, foreign secretary, says he wants to move “fast”, with ministers eyeing a vote as early as 2016.
Although European leaders frequently urge Mr Cameron to spell out exactly what he wants, the British prime minister’s negotiating demands are already in plain sight, set out in a series of speeches and newspaper articles. “We’ve already shown a lot of leg,” says one British official.
Mr Cameron has deliberately set the bar at what he believes is a realistic level — a view not shared in some other European capitals — because he wants to secure his objectives and then go on to campaign for Britain to stay in the EU. 
Although he leads a eurosceptic party, the majority of Conservative MPs see the case for remaining part of the world’s richest single market. David Davis, a hardline eurosceptic, estimates that some 60 of the total 331 Tory MPs will vote for a Brexit whatever deal Mr Cameron negotiates in Brussels. But dozens of others are waiting to see: if the prime minister fails to get a better deal, the party’s uneasy peace on Europe could be blown apart. 
British public opinion, according to most polls, is in favour of the country staying in, but last year’s close-run Scottish independence referendum is a reminder of how such votes can shred nerves. Although the main opposition parties, most business groups and the City of London will oppose Brexit, the debate would take place in a hostile eurosceptic media atmosphere. 
Mr Cameron needs a good deal in Europe and his strategy is built around three main areas: making the EU more competitive, reducing its power in relation to member states and curbing the access of migrant workers to British welfare — an attempt to allay public concerns about the scale of immigration.
Nick Clegg, the pro-European former leader of the Liberal Democrats, characterises Mr Cameron’s agenda as “motherhood and apple pie” and the main Labour opposition party broadly agrees. In other words, Mr Cameron’s stance is not the pipe dream of hardline Tory eurosceptics; it is in line with mainstream British political opinion.
While Mr Cameron’s approach is nowhere near tough enough for some in his party, the question is whether it goes too far for his negotiating partners.
There are two looming obstacles. The first is that eastern European countries are opposed to what they see as Mr Cameron’s discriminatory approach on benefits for migrant Poles, Lithuanians and others who come to Britain to work. 
“As soon as you have a discrimination between EU citizens it is forbidden in the treaties,” says Jean-Claude Piris, a former top legal adviser to EU leaders.
The second big problem is the opposition of virtually every EU member state to Mr Cameron’s desire for a “full-on treaty change” to enshrine his new deal. No country wants to go through the trauma of trying to ratify with a national referendum a new European treaty. Mr Hollande and Ms Merkel do not want British neuralgia interfering with their 2017 domestic election campaigns.
Mr Hammond said last week that treaty change was not needed “for the politics” but simply to ensure that an agreement was legally watertight. 
But senior British officials admit there is a significant risk of failure. There is concern Mr Hollande may scupper a deal, or that UK demands could trigger an unmanageable race for concessions from other member states.
Above all, senior EU officials say Britain’s growing marginalisation in Brussels will make it hard for Mr Cameron to demand favours. “The [Brits] must not overestimate their leverage — they’ve done so in the past. Solutions can be found,” says one senior official who will be closely involved in the talks. “But asking for too much, aiming high, will bring the negotiation to a dead end. Other member states have domestic politics to handle as well.”
Brussels officials say a deal is possible, provided Mr Cameron does not seek unrealistic changes to appease his own hardliners. The precedents are not auspicious: after all the prime minister only agreed to the referendum in the first place under pressure from his own eurosceptic MPs.

Summit talks on “the British question” were rolling into the second hour. Almost 20 leaders had spoken, most raising several gripes, some throwing barbs, others offering unsolicited political tips. David Cameron had heard enough.
A visibly frustrated British prime minister gave the kind of warning EU leaders understand all too well. “I can stay here all weekend if I need to,” he said, according to two diplomatic notes of the meeting. “I won’t go home with an insubstantial deal. We cannot weaken this text.” 
This was not the summit start Mr Cameron’s team was hoping for. Seven months of diplomatic hard slog seemed to dissipate as France, Belgium, Poland and Portugal led a gaggle of complainants picking apart the draft UK package. 
“I’m worried,” said one senior EU official who until now has been bullish about the deal. “This could be another bad case of them misreading each other.” At the very least, the talks are likely to run late into Friday afternoon.

He added that the talk “about ever closer union” came as “our borders are in danger and our European Union is disintegrating”. 
Mr Tsipras was not alone. António Costa, Portugal’s prime minister, lamented how “disappointing” it was that Mr Cameron had brought domestic political business to the European Council. “But I congratulate Cameron for his efforts,” he said.

Ms Merkel may give Mr Cameron some comfort on combating welfare abuse by EU migrants: members of her conservative CDU and its CSU have called for action. But, unlike Mr Cameron, the chancellor is a firm supporter of intra-EU migration.  
German officials say there can be no question of reimposing migration controls on the bloc’s newest members, Romania and Bulgaria. Mr Cameron has threatened to veto the entry of future new member states like Serbia and Albania unless new migrant curbs are agreed but there is little interest in Berlin in even discussing this. 
Berlin is worried that Britain is moving down a road that could, with a planned referendum on EU membership, result in its leaving the union.
Thomas Matussek, a former ambassador to the UK and now head of the Alfred Herrhausen Society, a think-tank, says: “We would like to help to keep Britain inside. But we can only keep the door open. Walking through the door must be done by the British themselves.”
Ms Merkel is likely to make the same point.

David Cameron celebrated his 49th birthday on Friday night with Angela Merkel at Chequers, although the festivities were clouded by questions over Britain’s EU future, the Syrian refugee crisis and Ukraine.
Mr Cameron and Ms Merkel enjoy warm relations and have spent many convivial hours in the Buckinghamshire countryside, but Friday night’s meeting and dinner was dominated by serious business.
The UK prime minister wants his German counterpart to help him inject political energy into Britain’s EU renegotiation, which is mired in technical talks in Brussels, with a view to making substantial progress before the end of the year.
The task has been given new urgency, as one putative Brexit campaign was launched on Thursday night with an analysis of the costs of Britain’s EU membership: Vote Leave has significant financial backing and cross-party support.
Mr Cameron’s team see the autumn as a chance for a new diplomatic offensive — a window between Poland’s general election on October 25 and the EU’s end-of-year summit on December 17 and 18.
“We want to talk about the next stage,” said one British official. 
But in Berlin there is considerable concern that Mr Cameron has so far failed to say explicitly what he wants — delaying the start of real negotiations.
Mr Cameron’s problem is that if he says precisely what he is seeking, his eurosceptic opponents will say it is not enough. If the prime minister then secures only some of what he wants, his problem is compounded.
Charles Grant, director of the Centre for European Reform, has studied the UK-German relationship and says the British side feels that the Germans “aren’t being as helpful as they might be” on the question of welfare for migrant workers.
Meanwhile, he says Ms Merkel’s team views as “special pleading” British demands for protection for non-eurozone countries and their place in the EU single market. “They see it as crude protectionism for the City,” he said.
One option being promoted by Britain is for the EU to be reconfigured as a two-pillar structure, with the single market kept completely separate from the closer integration envisaged for the eurozone.
Regarding refugees, German politicians have expressed frustration at the UK’s unwillingness to participate more fully in Berlin-led efforts to spread the burden of the migration crisis from the countries taking the largest numbers: Germany, Austria and Sweden.
There was more agreement on Friday night on the need to retain EU sanctions on Russia if it failed to honour its commitments to pull back from Ukraine; Mr Cameron and Ms Merkel are both hawkish on the issue.
Ms Merkel has frequently reminded Mr Cameron that she cannot deliver EU reform on her own, and the British prime minister has recently broadened his diplomatic effort to the 26 other European leaders.
However, the two leaders retain considerable empathy for each other’s concerns and in the past have whiled away hours at Chequers watching DVDs of Midsomer Murders, one of Ms Merkel’s favourite shows.
Mr Cameron likes to take visitors to the spot on Coombe Hill where he stood with the German chancellor admiring the English countryside: “As I said to Angela, if things had been different all this could have been yours,” he jokes.
Contrary to earlier reports, Ms Merkel did not stay over at Chequers: she returned to Berlin after dinner, leaving Mr Cameron to spend the rest of his birthday with his family.

US secretary of state John Kerry has intervened in the Brexit debate and urged the UK to stay in the EU. He said it was in the interests of the US as well as the EU that Britain remained a member.
Mr Kerry was speaking on Saturday at a security conference in Munich where the need for a strong EU to deal with the refugee crisis was high on the agenda.
He spoke the day after British prime minister David Cameron — in a speech in Hamburg — put security at the heart of his case for staying in the EU.
Mr Kerry said: “Europe is going to emerge stronger than ever, provided it stays united and builds common responses to these challenges.”
He added: “Now obviously, the United States has a profound interest in your success, as we do in a very strong United Kingdom staying in a strong EU.”
David Cameron on Friday night vowed that Britain would “not pull up the drawbridge and retreat from the world” as he put national security at the heart of his case for remaining in the EU.
Speaking in Hamburg at the ancient St Matthew’s feast with Angela Merkel looking on, Mr Cameron linked Britain’s EU membership to the fight against Isis.
Mr Cameron said: “Just as Europe has faced down dangerous and murderous ideologies in the past, so again we must stand together in this, the struggle of our generation, to confront this evil and defeat it.”
It was the prime minister’s last big speech before heading to Brussels next week to try to secure backing from 27 European leaders for his package of reforms to the EU.
Ms Merkel, the German chancellor, promised that she would do her best to help Mr Cameron get his deal, which will form the basis for a campaign to keep Britain in the EU at a referendum planned for June 23.
“We are convinced that from the German perspective, Great Britain remaining in the European Union is desirable,” she said. Ms Merkel pledged “to do everything with David Cameron to find a compromise”.
Christiane Wirtz, Ms Merkel’s deputy spokesperson, added that the chancellor was “optimistic” an agreement could be reached given “there is always a readiness to find a compromise in the EU”.
The two leaders travelled to Hamburg — which sees itself as Germany’s most Anglophile city — in a gesture of solidarity. Mr Cameron invoked the Hanseatic League as evidence that Germany and Britain shared a vision of an outward-looking, trading Europe.
“The strongest part of our relationship is our shared values and beliefs,” Mr Cameron said. “We all believe in the importance of trade, and that has been the case for centuries.”
While Mr Cameron’s referendum campaign will rest primarily on the economic advantages of EU membership, a strong secondary theme will be based on national security.
“In a world where Russia is invading Ukraine and a rogue nation like North Korea is testing nuclear weapons, we need to stand up to this aggression together,” he said.
He said European countries should “bring our economic might to bear on those who rip up the rule book and threaten the safety of our people”.
Speaking before the Hamburg dinner, Ms Wirtz said Mr Cameron’s final deal would not be a “Lex Britannica”, a set of exceptions that would apply only to the UK. In other words, the proposed reforms, including rights for governments to limit EU migrants welfare, would be valid for all EU members. 
Ms Merkel is due to see Donald Tusk, European Council president, in Berlin on Tuesday in a final face-to-face exchange before the summit next Thursday and Friday. 
A key issue is Mr Tusk’s plans for limits on EU migrants’ welfare, which he has put forward in response to Britain’s demands for cuts. Ms Merkel is not expected to raise substantial objections as long as the freedom of movement of workers is not infringed. 
Mr Cameron is hoping to negotiate a new settlement between Britain and the 27 other members of the EU before a promised referendum on the UK’s continued participation in a reformed Europe
There are also divisions — discussed by EU finance ministers on Friday — between London on the one hand and Berlin and Paris on the other over rules governing relations between the 19-member eurozone and non-eurozone states, such as the UK. 
Germans broadly want the UK to stay in the EU — but not at any price. In a YouGov poll this month, 59 per cent said they would prefer Britain to remain a member, against 18 per cent who said the UK should leave, with the rest undecided. Moreover, Germans see Brexit as increasingly possible — 47 per cent think the UK could go its own way.

When Harold Wilson’s government sought to renegotiate the terms of Britain’s EU membership in 1974 the stiffest resistance, unsurprisingly, came from France. Jean Sauvagnargues, the then French foreign minister, said London’s wish list was “wholly contrary to the very spirit of the community”. Paris went to the wire before acquiescing in more favourable arrangements for imports of New Zealand butter.
In the circumstances George Osborne, the UK chancellor, is wise to spend some quality time in Paris. Laurent Fabius, the present occupant of the Quai D’Orsay, has echoed his predecessor in observing that Britain cannot expect to join a football club and then demand to play by the rules of rugby.
Officials close to Germany’s Angela Merkel predict that this second renegotiation will at some point provoke a public blow-up between Britain and its EU partners, probably at the Brussels summit in December. An agreement will be reached only if and when London and Paris bridge their differences. Historical and cultural rivalry as well as realpolitik will weigh. It is no accident that the two nations are often described as the best of enemies. 
Thus far Mr Cameron’s government has adopted a softly-softly approach. Extravagant pre-election demands for “full-on treaty change” and silly jibes at France’s economic troubles have made way for a more measured process. Sensibly, the prime minister has offered publicly only a broad outline of Britain’s proposals. 
The hard bargaining has been passed to diplomats and officials in Brussels. Anxious at once to minimise and postpone the expected revolt by eurosceptics in his own party against any agreement, Mr Cameron has avoided hostages to fortune. Never one for grappling with detail, he has also delegated to the chancellor the day-to-day co-ordination of the negotiations. 
British calls for the EU to set an agenda grounded in economic competitiveness and growth will garner plenty of support in other capitals. Berlin has indicated it can probably grin and bear Mr Cameron’s call for Britain to be exempted from the ill-defined EU goal of “ever-closer union”. Sweden, Poland and other euro-outs may be persuaded to back guarantees against eurozone caucusing. The trickiest discussions are likely be over London’s attempt to restrict in-work benefits for EU workers and dilute common social policies.
Mr Cameron has a clear interest in an early settlement. A deal in December should allow a vote next June, minimising the inevitable distractions and disruptions of the referendum campaign. The government will hope that the present economic recovery will carry through at least until next summer. Finally a mid-2016 referendum should escape the shadow of midterm blues. 
Other EU governments also have an incentive to resolve the issue. The Greek deal has scarcely fixed the euro, while violent chaos to the south and Russian aggression to the east demand much more of the EU’s attention. And for all that Britain is an awkward bedfellow, the union would be seriously weakened by its departure
Mr Cameron should take nothing for granted. France, rightly, will fiercely resist anything that unravels the basic principle of free movement within the EU. Ms Merkel sees herself as guardian of the EU’s broader acquis. And each of Britain’s 27 EU partners have their own domestic politics to contend with. It is often said that when Paris and Berlin agree, the EU works. In this case, if Britain and France can reach an accommodation then a deal should be possible to maximise the chances of avoiding Brexit.

David Cameron, Britain’s prime minister, arrives in Brussels on Thursday for an EU budget summit intent on following the advice he once offered his party: “Stop banging on about Europe.”
Mr Cameron’s first European outing since he announced a 2017 referendum on Britain’s EU membership has been viewed with trepidation in other capitals, as the 27-country bloc prepares to hammer out a new seven-year budget.
British leaders going back to Margaret Thatcher have turned these summits into flag-waving confrontations, with the UK fighting to cut French farm subsidies and staging a doughty defence of Britain’s €3.5bn budget rebate.
But Mr Cameron has approached this summit wearing the political equivalent of an invisibility cloak: the premier’s week has been dominated by his plan to legalise gay marriage and a hospital scandal – he has barely uttered a word on Europe.
The prime minister’s attempt to dial down the European rhetoric and secure a low-key conclusion to Brussels budget talks partly reflects his desire to reassure fellow EU leaders that he is not out to wreck the union.
But it is also a sign of Mr Cameron’s acute awareness that the British public find his Conservative party’s obsession with Europe baffling. “It barely registers on their list of concerns,” said Lord Ashcroft, a senior party figure and pollster.
Mr Cameron says he wants to play “a constructive” part in Thursday’s budget negotiations, while fighting for a real-terms budget cut. A seven-year payments figure of about €900bn and cuts to the Brussels bureaucracy would probably suffice.
The figures are moving towards a zone where Mr Cameron can claim success: indeed the EU budget figures are so complex he could claim a victory given almost any outcome and be guaranteed a warm reception from Tory MPs when he returns.
Mr Cameron’s real focus is on the medium term and a referendum strategy which only comes into focus if he wins the 2015 British election. In the meantime a softer approach suits his domestic and European agenda.
At home he wants to avoid any EU confrontations, including another budget row, which inflame the passions of his eurosceptic party, or fuel British business concerns that Mr Cameron is edging the UK towards the exit.
Meanwhile he wants to reassure European leaders that he genuinely wants to keep Britain in the club, albeit on new terms, in the hope that they might eventually agree to cut him some kind of deal.
William Hague, Britain’s foreign secretary, insisted to MPs on Wednesday that other countries saw merit in the prime minister’s vision of a looser EU with less regulation and a greater focus on competition. “They want to work with the UK,” he said.
In an attempt to strengthen his European alliances, Mr Cameron has used the budget talks to work closely with fellow fiscal disciplinarians – led by Germany’s Angela Merkel and including the Dutch and the Swedes.
However Ms Merkel has warned Mr Cameron that he cannot “cherry pick” the parts of EU treaties that he likes, fearing that it could lead to the single market unravelling.
Mr Cameron has a bigger problem with François Hollande, France’s Socialist president, who has warned that “Europe à la carte” is not on the table, especially if the British premier thinks he can unstitch the social fabric of the EU.
However the Elysée Palace has indicated that Mr Hollande is willing to discuss reforms if Mr Cameron is genuinely talking about changes that would benefit the whole EU.
British officials hope that Mr Cameron has bolstered his credentials in Paris as a good European by supporting the French mission in Mali – Britain was the first country to offer its backing.
Bernard Emié, French ambassador to London, agreed this week that Mali was perhaps a pointer to the future.
“The term solidarity isn’t used much by British officials – they’d rather use the terms value for money or we want our money back,” he said. “But the Malian operation is very important because the Brits were the first.”

Angela Merkel will join David Cameron on Wednesday in calling for reforms to the EU. But the German chancellor will urge the UK prime minister not to push her too far in his demands for a renegotiation of bloc treaties.
Ms Merkel, on a visit to London, will back the UK premier’s call for Europe to be more open, fiscally responsible and less bureaucratic, and endorse efforts to conclude a transatlantic trade deal with the US.
But in private talks in Downing Street she is expected to remind Mr Cameron that Germany will not back any British demands for a major rewrite of existing EU treaties before the prime minister’s proposed in-out referendum.
Mr Cameron has in recent days said his proposed reforms would require treaty change, while Ms Merkel opposes any British deal that would lead to an unstitching of EU treaties or require ratification by referendums in any member state.
The chancellor is likely to set out her ground rules for any negotiations with Mr Cameron, 
if he wins this year’s general election, at a press conference in Downing Street on Wednesday evening.
Pat McFadden, Labour’s Europe spokesman, says Berlin wants Mr Cameron to show leadership and that there is exasperation in Germany that it is expected to bail out the eurozone and sort out the “British problem”.
Mr McFadden, who met senior German officials recently, wrote in an article for Progress website: “She will of course urge him to keep Britain inside Europe but she is also likely to reflect German concerns that there is a danger of him and his party expecting too much of Germany.”
Ms Merkel would ideally like to stay out of the British election campaign: the chancellor’s visit is primarily to discuss her agenda for the G7 group of leading economies this year before a June summit in Bavaria.
She will also take in a visit to the British Museum’s highly acclaimed Germany exhibition and meet its director Neil MacGregor, a German speaker who is coveted in Berlin as a potential chief of the new Humboldt Forum museum.
Ms Merkel will not meet Ed Miliband on the visit: the Labour leader’s office says it has not sought a meeting and it was unaware that the chancellor was coming to London until it was too late.
But Ms Merkel knows that the media will be eager to hear her views on Mr Cameron’s negotiating position, having previously indicated that she feared that the British premier was taking his country towards exit from the EU.
The German chancellor has warm relations with Mr Cameron, punctuated by episodes of misunderstanding leading to mutual disappointment.
In a joint statement before the meeting, Mr Cameron and Ms Merkel said: “We must do more to make the EU more stable and competitive than it is today. We have both taken steps at home to consolidate our public finances and it is important that we continue to pursue this long term plan.
“We must do more to harness the potential of the single market and reduce regulation that is hampering business. We must also dismantle further barriers to trade, in particular by agreeing an EU-US trade deal in 2015, which was launched at the UK’s G8 summit in Lough Erne.”
Peter Wilding, director of the pro-European British Influence lobby group, said the UK prime minister must reassure Ms Merkel that he does not want the upheaval of European treaty change.
“David Cameron must ignore the europhobes and stop ratcheting up his rhetoric on EU reforms,” Mr Wilding said. “Demands for treaty change and threats of Brexit [British exit] won’t win back a single Ukip [UK Independence party] vote and will only alienate powerful allies like chancellor Merkel, who are determined to keep Britain in the EU but won’t take kindly to blackmail.”

Angela Merkel embraced the UK 
on Wednesday with a powerful speech recalling Britain’s wartime sacrifices in an effort to calm the dispute over Jean-Claude Juncker’s bid for the EU’s top job and to dispel fears of Britain leaving the union. 
Speaking to the Bundestag just before the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings, the German chancellor endorsed Britain’s role in Europe and the EU, saying the UK had “no need to prove its European credentials”.
The German chancellor repeated her support for Mr Juncker’s candidacy for the European Commission presidency, which David Cameron, UK prime minister, has vehemently opposed. But she did so in matter-of-fact terms: she reserved her passion for an emotional appeal for Britain’s continued EU membership, condemning as “gross negligence” any “loose talk” of Britain’s leaving.
Mr Cameron privately welcomed Ms Merkel’s words and is expected to have informal talks with the chancellor at the Group of Seven summit in Brussels, which start on Wednesday night.
Meanwhile, in an attempt to improve the climate, Mr Cameron persuaded Conservative MEPs to postpone until next week a vote on whether to form an alliance in the European Parliament with Alternative für Deutschland, the anti-euro party that is seen by Ms Merkel as a rival to her own conservative Christian Democratic Union/Christian Social Union alliance.
However, as a British diplomat put it, Ms Merkel remains “between a rock and a hard place”. The 28 EU government heads are to decide on the replacements for the current commission when its term ends this year.
But the parliament has tried to pre-empt them and boost its influence by backing Mr Juncker following his success in the recent European elections. He was the lead candidate of the centre-right European People’s party, which emerged as the biggest grouping.
In Germany, the CDU/CSU and its Social Democrat coalition partners immediately threw their weight behind Mr Juncker, arguing that this was the democratic choice. German media have mostly backed the campaign, with some publications warning Mr Cameron against “blackmailing” the rest of the EU by threatening to leave, a reference to his planned membership referendum.
Ms Merkel has pledged to stick to the EPP and German line but wants to find a deal acceptable to other EU members, including the UK. This could be based on a broader package of top EU jobs and agreed EU policy commitments. In the meantime she wants to reassure Mr Cameron that she will do what she can to help him.
In her speech, the chancellor said: “I think it is gross negligence, indeed unacceptable, how casual some people are in saying “it’s all the same how the UK votes or whether it remains an EU member or not . . . It is certainly not all the same.”
While saying that Britain was “certainly not a comfortable partner”, the country had benefited much from Europe and had given much, Ms Merkel said. She quoted from former German president Richard von Weizsäcker’s 1986 speech in the British parliament in which he said: “Where would Europe be today if the British people had not found the strength to risk their own existence in order to preserve the hopes of all European people for a better peaceful future? Britain has no need to prove its European credentials.”
The reference recalled her own visit to the UK earlier this year, when she too addressed both houses of parliament, and spoke in favour of German-British co-operation in Europe.

The coming referendum on Britain’s place in Europe promises a choice between an unavoidably uncomfortable future and comforting nostalgia for a more predictable past. This collision of realism with emotion sets the quest for security and prosperity in a world that no longer belongs to the west against hankering for the days when Britain made the global rules. 
The choice is not readily distilled for the ballot paper. David Cameron’s government intends to reframe it with the promise of a “new deal” for Britain in a “reformed” Union. Europe’s perennial outlier, the prime minister’s pitch has it, can hold on to the benefits of membership while exempting itself from the integrationist ambitions of its partners. A favoured phrase in Downing Street these days is “the best of both worlds”.
Mr Cameron has told fellow leaders he would like an agreement by the end of the year. The date for the plebiscite has yet to be fixed, but he wants to keep open the option of late spring or early summer 2016. That means striking a deal at the December Brussels summit. British officials describe this timetable as demanding but achievable.
An accord has been made more possible by Mr Cameron’s willingness to retreat from what were once pivotal demands — “full-on treaty change” and restrictions on the free movement of people across the Union. On the first of these, Britain would now be content with a protocol modelled on that given to the Copenhagen government after Danish voters repudiated the Maastricht treaty in 1992. 
Such an agreement would be binding on the other 27 EU states, and, where necessary, its provisions would be incorporated into the EU treaties when they were next renegotiated. As regards free movement, the British goal has been revised to restrict in-work benefits for those arriving from other EU states. Both of these look like plausible, if not easy, ambitions.
Negotiations are picking up pace. Mr Cameron’s latest meetings with François Hollande, the French president, and Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, have been accompanied by a great deal of diplomatic paddling below the water. The British side admits, though. it has been reluctant to set down any details in formal texts. Officials fear that, like many other secret EU documents, they would quickly find their way on to the newspaper’s Brussels editor Peter Spiegel. 
Mr Cameron, who has all but bet his premiership on securing a “yes” in the referendum, plans a second round of bilateral talks with each and everyone of his EU counterparts. He will add a rare excursion to Strasbourg to put his case directly to the European parliament. By some estimates, Whitehall has had more contact with EU parliamentarians during the past six months than during the preceding 10 years.
As for substance, the British demands now fall into four baskets. The first covers a general exhortation that the Union should be more competitive — extending the single market, scrapping needless regulation. and such like. Some would say this is motherhood and apple pie. The second is about drawing clearer lines between members of the euro and those who have kept hold of their own currencies, or more specifically guarantees that the former will not ride roughshod over the latter and so damage the City of London. A third deals with the vexed question of in-work benefits for EU nationals in Britain. The fourth would allow national parliaments to apply a brake on Brussels legislation, for greater subsidiarity and, very specific to Britain, for an opt-out from the notional EU goal of ever-closer union. 
There is no guarantee of a deal. Ms Merkel, Mr Hollande and the rest have one or two other things on their mind — Syria, a refugee crisis and Russian mischief in Ukraine among them. Greece could destabilise the euro again at any moment. These other leaders, as they have doubtless told Mr Cameron, also have domestic political constituencies to satisfy. For all the diplomacy, things will get tougher once the wish list begins to be translated into legal texts. All that said, the others scarcely want to see Britain leave. The Germans, as the former chancellor Konrad Adenauer once said, do not look like the idea of being left alone with the French. The feeling is reciprocated in Paris.
Mr Cameron’s strategy is clear enough. Wrap up a modest package of concessions and the symbolic disavowal of ever closer union with existing opt-outs from the euro, the Schengen open borders system and some judicial affairs and he can claim that Britain has stepped off the fabled Franco-German locomotive of European integration. There is something in this too for its partners. Safe on the platform, London will no longer throw boulders on to the tracks if they choose to steam ahead.
The political calculation here is that, while voters may be oblivious to the detail of any package negotiated in Brussels, they will grasp the idea that Britain has set itself apart. 
What this misses is the emotional force of the (duplicitous) claim that, if only it strikes out on its own, Britain can take back full command of its destiny. The clinching case for EU membership has always been the hard-headed assessment that, in a world in which power is shifting elsewhere, Britain’s interests are best safeguarded within the club. This is not the easiest of sells. But all the rest is window dressing.
