David Cameron was unequivocal on Monday as he addressed MPs: Britain would not be stumping up an additional £1.7bn in contributions to the EU.
To the cheers of his backbenchers, the prime minister vowed to “crawl through” the extra bill “in exhaustive detail”, rejecting the payment’s size and a five-week deadline for paying it. The EU says the extra contribution for the years 2002-13 has been triggered by a recent upward revision to the UK’s gross national income during that period.
Mr Cameron’s outburst reflected anxiety in Downing Street at the advance of Ukip ahead of next May’s general election. A surge in support for the anti-Brussels party this year has encouraged defections from Conservative ranks and emboldened vocal Tory eurosceptics.
“It is British taxpayers’ money and it is not small change and it is a vast sum,” Mr Cameron said. “We will be challenging this in every way possible.”
Ed Miliband retorted that the prime minister’s “last-minute pyrotechnics” at a Brussels summit last week could not disguise that the government had failed to do “due diligence” on the EU budget recalculation.
The Labour leader, citing both the Treasury and the Office for National Statistics, said revisions to gross national income and contributions to the EU budget had been flagged in March and then again in May. Mr Cameron, he said, was “asleep at the wheel”. Conservative former chancellor Ken Clarke made a similar suggestion, saying Mr Cameron had been taken by surprise on an issue that “everybody in the Foreign Office and the Treasury” knew was coming.
However, with the threat of more Tory defections and a looming defeat at the hands of Ukip in the Rochester & Strood by-election, the salience of the European issue is never far from Mr Cameron’s mind. 
Support for Ukip has surged to a record high in the wake of the surcharge row, according to a ComRes survey for the Independent. 
It puts Ukip on 19 per cent, a jump of four points on last month and one point above its previous record support in June.
In another attempt to outflank Ukip, Downing Street has ordered officials to consider ways of limiting the migration of EU workers from existing member states.
However, the prime minister’s rhetoric on limiting the movement of workers and on not paying the EU budget surcharge contrasts with the reality that the room for manoeuvre on both issues is very limited under the bloc’s rules. 
Making undeliverable demands does little more than leave the prime minister cornered, argues one despairing former Tory minister.
Not only can he not keep his promises, he is also testing his relationship with his main ally, Angela Merkel, which could imperil his hopes of renegotiating Britain’s EU membership terms.  
On migration, the prime minister has little hope of revising the principle of freedom of movement: Ms Merkel is resolute. “Germany will not tamper with the fundamental principles of free movement in the EU,” she said over the weekend.
As for the rebate, the prime minister did not rule out paying some form of contribution, in an admission that the UK cannot ignore the rules. 
The UK intends to challenge the size of the surcharge on two fronts: it wants to make sure that all member states included the same categories – prostitution and drugs – in their gross national income calculations. It will also demand that the commission reassess whether extra payments from the UK should then be redistributed to 13 member states that have joined since 2004. 
Mr Cameron has raised expectations that he can win this budget battle. But one government figure concedes whatever he does agree won’t be enough for many Tory eurosceptics who believe the government should refuse to pay at all. 
“He spends all this time negotiating with his party about Europe . . . when he should be getting a better deal for Britain in Europe,” said Mr Miliband. 
Mark Pritchard, a backbench MP, said the events of the past few days had only made Mr Cameron’s job with his party harder. “Europe needs to work with the UK not against the UK and the events of the past few days has not helped the PM in wanting to have an objective, measured and rational debate about Europe.” . . .
Word versus deeds

Freedom of movement
The rhetoricDavid Cameron moves beyond his original aims of clamping down on so-called “benefit tourism” and preventing “mass migrations” from new accession countries such as Turkey to a broader aim of limiting migration of workers from existing EU members. “Numbers that have increased faster than we in this country wanted at a level that was too much for our communities, for our labour markets – all this has to change,” he told delegates at the Conservative party conference. 
The realityMr Cameron has got some support from Germany and other European partners on his efforts to limit migrants’ access to benefits and control flows of workers from new accession countries. But more significant changes are a non-starter, as Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, made clear over the weekend: “Germany will not tamper with the fundamental principles of free movement.”
Jean-Claude Juncker
The rhetoricWhen Mr Cameron met the leaders of Germany, the Netherlands and Sweden in June to discuss who should hold Europe’s top job, he felt confident of gaining a consensus that it should not be Jean-Claude Juncker, the chosen candidateof the European Parliament. He told reporters: “As the democratically elected leaders of Europe, we should be the ones to choose who should run these institutions rather than accept some new process.”
The realityMr Cameron’s confidence came in part because he thought he had the backing of Ms Merkel. So he was shocked to see Ms Merkel give her backing to Mr Juncker just three days later. Having realised that domestic pressure in Germany meant she would not back down, the prime minister instead decided to issue a protest vote. Mr Juncker was appointed on a vote of 26-2.
EU budget
The rhetoricMr Cameron reacts with fury at the EU summit as he is presented with a demand to pay a €2.1bn budget surcharge to top up the EU’s budget by December 1. The prime minister describes himself as “downright angry” and characterises the presentation of the bill as an “appalling way to behave”. He insists the UK will not be paying it on December 1
The reality The Treasury was aware of a big upward revision to Britain’s national income by the Office for National Statistics. One Treasury minister was told about the changes on October 14, while the chancellor was told days ahead of the summit. While the bill looks large, it is a top-up to UK contributions covering 11 years and is in part a reflection of Britain’s strong economic performance. Officials are now querying the calculations but, in practice, the UK will settle some of this bill. Elizabeth Rigby and Kiran Stacey.

David Cameron insisted on Monday that his planned EU referendum was not scaring off inward investment to Britain, and denounced Labour for saying it would stay in an unreformed 28-member bloc “come what may”.

David Cameron’s hopes of winning backing for his European reform plans were dealt a blow on Thursday when his eurosceptic allies in the European parliament voted to embrace Angela Merkel’s political foes.
The move is a turning point for the ECR bloc, a group founded by Mr Cameron in 2009 that is providing a home to parties once seen to be on the margins of European politics, sometimes even when Downing Street opposes it.
Undermining the British prime minister’s standing with the powerful German chancellor, his European Conservatives and Reformists (ECR) bloc voted to ally with the anti-euro Alternative für Deutschland (AfD) – a party Ms Merkel views as an upstart populist rival. 
It was also a personal setback for the prime minister, who saw loyal Tory MEPs outgunned in a group that appears to be growing out of his control. The secret vote saw at least two of 19 Tories rebel, which was enough to swing the decision.
A spokesman for Mr Cameron said he was “very disappointed” over the AfD vote, which comes at a highly sensitive moment for Mr Cameron’s diplomatic push to speed up EU reform and block the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker, the Merkel-backed frontrunner to be the next European Commission president. 
Part of the pro-AfD majority also came from Danish and Finnish anti-immigration parties that were only admitted to ECR last week with Tory blessing, in spite of two of their MEPs carrying past convictions for inciting ethnic tension. 
Indeed Bernd Lucke, the AfD leader, is already facing brickbats in Germany over joining forces with the extremists in Mr Cameron’s group, whom Ska Keller, a German Green, described as “convicted rabble-rousers”. Mr Cameron’s team insists those MEPs have changed and are “now in the mainstream”.
The setback for Mr Cameron follows his leadership campaign pledge to break with the centre-right EPP, the parliament’s biggest group to which Ms Merkel’s CDU/CSU belongs. Ms Merkel saw the decision as a betrayal that she has struggled to forgive.
Although Tory MEPs deny it, diplomats and lobbyists say it diminished the UK’s influence just as Brussels was embarking on its most ambitious reform drive in the financial sector for a generation. 
Leaving the EPP also meant Mr Cameron was left out of the dealmaking last year when centre-right EU leaders chose Mr Juncker as their lead candidate in the European elections. “It was a fatal mistake,” said Simon Hix, a professor of European politics at the London School of Economics.  
By admitting new parties the ECR is growing in influence within the European parliament. A Thatcherite Tory – Syed Kamall – was yesterday elected the leader of the group. But the UK Tory delegation, making up 19 of 63 seats, now carries less sway in a bloc with more protectionist instincts.
Mr Cameron’s team attempted to limit the fallout with Ms Merkel by making clear their behind-the-scenes efforts. A Tory spokesman insisted that Ms Merkel’s CDU/CSU remained their “sister party”. The Christian Democratic Union, in turn, declined to comment in a clear bid not to aggregate tensions with the Tories. 
Charles Grant of the Centre for European Reform said the vote will not help Anglo-German relations “that were pretty bad before this point” over Mr Cameron’s outspoken objections to Mr Juncker. 
“The Tories are having to understand that Berlin won’t bail them out when they need help,” he said. “The British need to get real on Juncker. They have almost certainly lost the battle and need to start negotiating a good deal.”
Tory MEPs are now aggressively courting allies in the hope of making the ECR the European parliament’s third biggest group. The prize is more taxpayer funding – the ECR last year received around €3.8m in grants – and positions of influence on the important parliament committees that negotiate EU legislation. 
Mr Hix estimates the enlarged ECR could be sixth in line to choose a committee chair. This would be further increased if Beppe Grillo’s anti-establishment Five Star Movement join the ECR. The Italian group is holding a plebiscite on Thursday on whether to apply. 
Tories European friends
 Alternative für Deutschland
Founded just over a year ago, the AfD is a German conservative group that has carved out territory from the centre-right CDU/CSU. By campaigning largely against the euro, the AfD won 7 per cent in the European Parliament polls. Critics claim that underneath the polite exterior lurk elements of rightwing populism; an AfD youth branch, for example, recently called for vigilantes in response to crime. But under the disciplined leadership of Hamburg economics professor Bernd Lucke, 51, the party has mostly managed to maintain a moderate profile. While the AfD generally supports free trade, it is against parts of the EU-US trade deal, as currently proposed.
The Danish People’s party
The fiercely anti-immigration, pro-Church and royalist DPP has been a growing rightwing force in Danish politics for almost 20 years. Its breakthrough came in last month’s European elections, when it emerged as the biggest party with a 26 per cent share. It has frequently courted controversy: one MP once likened the Muslim headscarf to totalitarian symbols such as the swastika. The DPP is led in the European parliament by Morten Messerschmidt, a young and charismatic politician who was convicted in 2002 for publishing material that appeared to link a multi-ethnic society to rape, violence and forced marriages. The ECR are satisfied that his views have changed. On joining the British-led ECR, Mr Messerschmidt joked: “today you can call me Mr Spitfire”.

The True Finns
Led by Timo Soini, a diehard Millwall football club fan, the True Finns are a party with agrarian roots that has made strides in Finnish politics on an anti-EU, anti-bailout platform. It won almost a fifth of the votes in 2011 general election, making it the biggest opposition party. The party draws support from across the political spectrum and Mr Soini strongly denies it harbours racists. Jussi Halla-aho, a newly elected MEP, was convicted in 2012 of stirring ethnic tensions after claiming that Islam “reveres paedophilia” in a blog intended to test the limits of freedom of speech.

David Cameron ended his tour of European capitals with stern warnings from Poland over his plans to curb benefits for migrants. But he got a warmer welcome from Angela Merkel and an offer to help him win his referendum on British membership of the EU.
The British prime minister arrived in Berlin, the last stop of a sometimes awkward two-day tour, to be told by Ms Merkel that Germany wanted the UK to stay in the EU and help to make the bloc more competitive and less bureaucratic. 
The German chancellor also left open the prospect of treaty change, declaring: “Where there’s a will, there’s a way.”
Talks in Warsaw beforehand were more difficult, however. Ewa Kopacz, the Polish prime minister, told Mr Cameron she would fight any proposal “that could lead to the discrimination of Poles or other EU citizens working legally in Great Britain”, her office said.
This came after a senior aide to Mrs Kopacz said Poland, which has about 800,000 citizens living in the UK, would say a “definite no” to the British government’s plans to make it harder for EU migrants to claim benefits. Poles comprise the largest group of EU nationals resident in Britain.
Mr Cameron was warned on Thursday by François Hollande, French president, that there could be no EU treaty change to enshrine Britain’s proposed reforms before presidential elections in 2017.
But one official close to the talks at the Elysée Palace said their working dinner was “cordial” and Mr Cameron had promised Mr Hollande that Britain was ready to take a bigger role in global affairs after several years of introspection.
The official said Mr Cameron acknowledged that the UK had been distracted by the Scottish referendum campaign and the general election, and that Britain stood ready to help France, the EU’s other big military power, to tackle concerns such as terrorism and the refugee crisis.
Mr Cameron appeared to blame Tony Blair, rather than eurosceptic Conservative MPs, for the fact that he is holding an EU referendum. 
The prime minister told his French host that pressure for a vote had been building ever since Mr Blair ratified the EU’s Lisbon treaty in 2008 without holding his promised plebiscite.
Ms Merkel, addressing a joint press conference with Mr Cameron at the chancellery in Berlin, struck a pragmatic tone, saying it was vital first to establish exactly what limits the British prime minister wanted to impose on welfare payments to migrants.
“You cannot completely rule out treaty change if it’s necessary to do that,” she said.

The chancellor added that case law from the European Court of Justice could lead to changes in Germany’s rules on benefits for migrants. 
The key ruling from the ECJ relates to a Romanian woman who claimed benefits in Leipzig; the court ruled last year that Germany could deny benefits to “economically inactive” migrants from other EU states.
Meanwhile Mr Cameron said he wanted to see an EU that had “the flexibility of a network, not the rigidity of a bloc” where free trade and less red tape helped to raise economic growth.
Asked whether he could exclude campaigning for a British exit from the EU, Mr Cameron softened his usual line, suggesting he would only do so if other European leaders blocked all of his reforms.
“If I was to achieve none of these things I rule nothing out,” he said. 
British officials said the two days of talks, which also included a meeting with Dutch premier Mark Rutte, had been “constructive”.
But they described the diplomacy as the first stage of a long process and played down speculation that Mr Cameron might present a final list of demands at the June European Council in Brussels.

David Cameron’s effort to renegotiate Britain’s relationship with Europe has been boosted after Germany said the EU had to ensure that the UK was legally protected from closer eurozone integration.
George Osborne, UK chancellor, and Wolfgang Schäuble, his German counterpart, say in a joint article in the Financial Times that any treaty change must “guarantee fairness” for EU countries that stay outside the eurozone. The commitment will be welcomed in the City of London, which fears a Europe where a core of 18 eurozone countries agree rules for the single market and effectively impose them on all 28 member states.
Berlin wants treaty change to overhaul the single currency’s governance, including creating a “budget commissioner” empowered to use common funds and reject national fiscal plans that threaten the euro’s stability.
But the German government has now gone a step further, arguing in the FT that treaty change must also address one of key negotiating demands of Mr Cameron, the UK prime minister, before his planned 2017 referendum: the protection of the interests of euro “outs”.
“As the euro area continues to integrate, it is important that countries outside the euro area are not at a systematic disadvantage in the EU,” Mr Schäuble and Mr Osborne write.
“So future EU reform and treaty change must include reform of the governance framework to put euro area integration on a sound legal basis and guarantee fairness for those EU countries inside the single market but outside the single currency.”
Germany’s desire for treaty change is not shared elsewhere in the EU, especially in France, which does not endorse Berlin’s enthusiasm for more centralised budgetary control in the eurozone.
There would also be widespread opposition to any treaty change that triggered referendums in any member state because the rise of populist and anti-European parties would make such polls a perilous exercise.
Mats Persson, director of the Open Europe think-tank, described Germany’s commitment as “a substantial win for Osborne and Cameron”.
He added: “This is the first time treaty changes for further eurozone integration and safeguarding the rights of non-euro countries have been linked by senior German and UK figures.”
The two finance ministers, who have a close relationship that mirrors the warm ties between Mr Cameron and Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, have given the commitment before informal talks in Cambridge on Friday.
Ms Merkel, who made a red carpet visit to London in February, said treaty change could be conducted in “a limited, targeted and speedy way”. Mr Cameron hopes that changes will fit into his referendum timetable.
Speaking in Bruges before travelling to Britain, Mr Schäuble said: “As long as the UK will not join the eurozone, maybe we can find a two-speed solution.”
Berlin’s openness to find a “fair” solution could rework and build on safeguards pegged to the deal to create a single eurozone supervisor, which required a “double majority” of euro and non-euro nations to pass technical financial rules.
Mr Cameron also said on Thursday that he was working with Ms Merkel and his Swedish and Dutch counterparts to review the benefits system for migrant workers in the EU. Although Germany is prepared to help Mr Cameron by offering single market safeguards, Ms Merkel is far less willing to concede any ground when it comes to his attempt to repatriate powers.
Mr Schäuble told Bruges’s College of Europe on Thursday that he wanted negotiations on a revised treaty to start straight after the European Parliament elections in May.
Downing Street said ministers had been engaged in “patient, quiet diplomacy” to secure Mr Cameron’s promised renegotiated settlement with the EU.
“Protecting the rights of non-eurozone countries as the eurozone integrates more deeply is right at the heart of our concerns – and this point is increasingly understood and accepted by our EU partners,” it said.

David Cameron arrives in Berlin on Wednesday in the slipstream of Elizabeth II, as he uses a state visit by the monarch to engage in some last- minute EU diplomacy with Angela Merkel, German chancellor.
British officials hope the emollient presence of the Queen in Berlin on the eve of a European summit will reinforce Ms Merkel’s willingness to help Mr Cameron keep the UK inside the EU.
“Queen Elizabeth is witness to the development of the relationship between Germany and Britain which is very friendly today,” Ms Merkel said this week ahead of the royal visit, which began on Tuesday night.
Friendly perhaps, but marred by a series of misunderstandings in which Mr Cameron has placed too much faith in Ms Merkel’s willingness or ability to fix his European problems.
On Thursday Mr Cameron will head to Brussels to set out his broad objectives for an EU renegotiation ahead of the UK’s planned referendum on membership, which Downing Street hopes to hold in 2016.
Mr Cameron hopes that Ms Merkel will back his plan to hand over detailed work on solving “the British question” to senior EU officials; he wants final proposals on the table at the December summit in Brussels.
No relationship in Europe is more important to the prime minister than the one with Ms Merkel — his officials refer to Germany as the G1 in the eurozone — but when put to the test it has often been found wanting.
Ms Merkel and Mr Cameron have shared interests in an open and competitive Europe and the two leaders have worked together in promoting trade deals, cutting the EU budget in 2013, and imposing sanctions on Russia over its incursion in Ukraine.
But on other issues things have not gone so well: Ms Merkel left Mr Cameron isolated in 2011 over a proposed EU fiscal pact, having initially said she would “find a way” to accommodate his demands.
She also offered to help Mr Cameron stop the appointment of Jean-Claude Juncker as European Commission president last year, only to leave the British leader virtually alone when she switched sides.
Gisela Stuart, a Labour MP born in Germany, says that although relations between Mr Cameron and Ms Merkel are “cordial”, there is a fundamental disconnect in the way they approach Europe.
“Cameron doesn’t understand that for Merkel the EU is existential — it is a fact of history and geography — it is not optional,” she said. The Greek debt crisis and the conflict in Ukraine are reminders that Ms Merkel has other concerns. 
Will Ms Merkel deliver for Mr Cameron on the biggest question of all? Observers of the last meeting between the two leaders noted how carefully the prime minister explored Ms Merkel’s willingness to back a UK deal.
Downing Street is carefully calibrating demands to ensure they do not stray across any Merkel red lines; indeed Mr Cameron’s big speech on EU migration last year was cleared in advance with Berlin.
But Mr Cameron has also been careful to follow the advice of Ms Merkel that he needs other allies; the British prime minister deliberately chose to visit Paris and Warsaw last month before touching down in Berlin.
Indeed by the start of the EU summit in Brussels he will have spoken to each of his fellow 27 leaders, along with Donald Tusk, the European Council president, and Mr Juncker, as well as leading MEPs.
Charles Grant, director of the Centre for European Reform, says: “Germans tell me that Merkel will lead from behind on this. She will work through Tusk and Juncker and keep the French by her side so people don’t have the perception she’s running the show.”

David Cameron warned there would be no shortcut to a better deal for Britain in the EU, as he arrived at a summit of European leaders to discuss his planned EU referendum. 
In a sign that Downing Street is looking to temper expectations as it embarks on negotiations, the prime minister urged patience and stressed his efforts would benefit the EU as a whole, not just the UK. 
“Today I will start discussions in earnest with fellow leaders on reforming the EU and renegotiating the UK’s relationship with it,” the prime minister said. 
“These talks will not be easy. They will not be quick. There will be different views and disagreements along the way. But by working together in the right spirit and sticking at it, I believe we can find solutions.”
The so-called “British question” is not strictly an agenda item at the summit in Riga, which is intended to engage with the EU’s eastern neighbours. 
However, Mr Cameron will use his first EU appearance since his election victory to begin sounding out fellow leaders over his reform wishlist, which ranges from cutting red tape and improving competitiveness to curbs on benefits for migrant workers.
He is to hold meetings on the sidelines with Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council who will play a key role in broking any UK deal, as well as the leaders of Poland, Latvia, Sweden and Hungary among others.
On arrival Mr Cameron noted there will be “ups and downs” in the process, as countries stake out their negotiating positions. “You’ll hear one day this is possible, the next day something else is impossible,” he said.
Alex Stubb, the outgoing Finnish premier, reflected the mood among many colleagues, saying he was “all ears” on British demands and interested in finding a good compromise. But he warned Finland will be against hurrying to change the EU treaties — something Mr Cameron ideally wants to see.

Their feedback will be particularly important in gauging whether it will be possible to hold a referendum earlier than the end of 2017 deadline Mr Cameron has set for a vote. 
The prime minister is considering holding the plebiscite earlier if possible, particularly given the reluctance of Angela Merkel and François Hollande, the leaders of France and Germany, to see negotiations intrude on their re-election campaigns in 2017. 
Some politicians and analysts have urged Mr Cameron to take his time and not hurry the negotiations if speed comes at the cost of important reforms that will take more time to work through the EU system.
When asked about the British question, Mr Hollande shrugged and said: “It is not for tonight.” 
Other leaders were more open about their willingness to work with Mr Cameron to find a referendum-winning deal. 
Taavi Roivas, Estonia’s prime minister, said he was unwilling to curtail the basic freedoms of the EU — such as free movement of people and labour — but he left open the possibility of treaty changes, if that proved necessary.
“If we agree what we want to achieve then we definitely don’t say that treaty change is an absolute impossibility,” he said. “But let’s first agree on what we want to achieve, how to achieve it and then we can decide on the means.”
Helle Thorning-Schmidt, Denmark’s prime minister, congratulated Mr Cameron on his “fantastic victory” in the general election and said she hoped it would be possible to “find good solutions for Britain”.
On the issue of treaty change — a drawn-out process that could trigger referendums in other countries — she said: “We have to listen to what Mr Cameron has to say about what kind of changes they want to achieve and then we will take it from there.”

David Cameron’s relations with Angela Merkel face a test next week as the British premier’s eurosceptic allies in Brussels decide whether to join forces with Germany’s anti-euro Alternative für Deutschland.

When Angela Merkel arrives in Britain on Thursday for a one-day visit, she will receive the full red-carpet treatment. Not only will she address both houses of parliament at Westminster, a rare honour accorded to few leaders; Ms Merkel will also take tea with the Queen at Buckingham Palace.
The lavish nature of her reception not only reflects her position as the most powerful politician in Europe. It also underscores how central the UK’s prime minister, David Cameron, deems her acquiescence to be to his hopes of successfully renegotiating Britain’s relations with the EU.
For the British government – and especially the Conservative party – this renegotiation has become the central foreign policy goal of our time. The finest minds in Whitehall have been set the task of weighing the balance of competences between London and Brussels.
The prime minister’s problem is that few other countries share his priorities. Mr Cameron needs to hammer out a new deal to fit the political timetable he has mapped for himself, which envisages a referendum on Britain’s membership of the EU in 2017. But there is little evidence that his EU partners are approaching the question with similar urgency. 
In London, Ms Merkel will listen to Mr Cameron sympathetically. She understands his wish to give more power to national parliaments and shares his distaste for benefit tourism. But she must weigh his pleas for action against the wishes of other leading EU governments, which are extremely wary of treaty change. And even if a more informal repatriation of powers can take place, this is unlikely to appeal to Tory backbenchers whose demands are radical to the point of unreality.
Ms Merkel may, however, remind Mr Cameron that there are other, more pressing issues on Europe’s agenda. And this points to what is the most striking feature of her visit: that at a time when Europe is confronting the crisis in Ukraine – one of the biggest challenges since the fall of the Berlin Wall – the British continue to obsess about the minutiae of the EU’s rule book.
For Ms Merkel, a politician whose life has been defined by the cold war, this must be remarkable. After the events of 1989, Margaret Thatcher and John Major championed the enlargement of the EU to the newly liberated nations of central and eastern Europe. Other EU states, notably France, were sceptical. But for those Conservative leaders, enlargement was bound up with questions of democracy and freedom from oppression. Contrast that with today’s Tory party, for which any mention of eastern Europe conjures up images of migrants and benefit-scroungers. 
Mr Cameron’s government would do well to reflect on where that attitude is leaving Britain in European affairs. Last Friday the foreign ministers of France, Germany and Poland brokered a deal in Kiev that stabilised Ukraine’s crisis. Although it was overturned by events, it halted the bloodshed and was an important achievement. Britain – which under a Thatcher, Major or Blair would have been at the table – was absent. Indeed, Britain’s role in Europe is slowly being supplanted by Poland, whose political establishment is determined to make their country a frontline power militarily and diplomatically.
Of course, this is not how things need develop. Ms Merkel wants Britain to stay in the EU, knowing the union’s standing would be diminished by the UK’s departure. But the reality is inescapable. Ms Merkel will get the red carpet from a British government with narrowing diplomatic ambitions and an increasingly introverted approach to Europe. This is a Britain slowly moving to the sidelines of world affairs.

Other member states including France and Italy are expected to back Ms Merkel over the appointment of Mr Juncker; both countries are hoping for a deal in which Brussels relaxes its demands for austerity.
Sir John Major, former British prime minister, claimed on Wednesday that Mr Cameron might then expect other concessions if he is outvoted over Mr Juncker, but the political damage to his authority will be considerable.
One face-saving option may be for Mr Cameron to be offered a “package” of top jobs more acceptable to London, although Brussels officials said there was no sense of urgency around filling other posts.
Ms Merkel is meeting Helle Thorning-Schmidt, Denmark’s prime minister, on Thursday, sparking speculation she might be lined up to replace Herman Van Rompuy as president of the European Council.
Ms Thorning-Schmidt is the daughter-in-law of former British Labour leader Neil Kinnock and is well-liked in London. Martin Selmayr, Mr Juncker’s campaign chief, has speculated that Radoslaw Sikorski, the Oxford-educated Polish foreign minister, might become EU foreign affairs chief.
Opposition to Mr Juncker has weakened to such an extent that some EU officials believe it is now unnecessary to discuss his candidacy as part of a package of top EU jobs, a practice frequently used in the past as a way of horse-trading support from reluctant member states.
Senior EU officials involved in negotiations said Mr Juncker’s appointment is now all but assured for Friday, day two of next week’s summit, which will begin with a dinner in Ypres and move on to Brussels.
Mr Van Rompuy had considered postponing the “jobs” discussion to avoid an Anglo-German dispute at Ypres, the site of fierce fighting between the two countries in the first world war, but has now decided to press ahead. 
Ms Merkel’s decision to back a quick decision to avoid domestic political upheaval has largely killed any hope of delaying his nomination, officials said.
“What would be the advantage of postponement?” said one EU official involved in the talks. “It would only be an advantage if you have an alternate solution or there’s a chance of a better solution emerging. There isn’t.”
Although there is little sympathy for Mr Cameron’s dilemma in some EU quarters, particularly in France, other British allies in Brussels and northern EU capitals are worried what his loss could mean for the UK’s long-term relationship with Brussels.
Still, officials believe Ms Merkel is now unwilling to buck senior members of her own Christian Democratic Union party who are pushing for Mr Juncker’s nomination and German public opinion, which is increasingly critical of her earlier attempts to placate Mr Cameron.
